summary: HTNV is a member of the enveloped Bunyaviridae family. the large (L) segment encodes the viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), the medium (M) segment encodes two surface glycoproteins (Gn and Gc), and the small (S) segment encodes the nucleocapsid protein (NP) at present, the pathogenesis of HFRS is still unclear. 3, CXCL10 induces chemotaxis, apoptosis, cell growth inhibition, and angiostasis [6]. the elevated level of CXCL10 has been found to be correlated with the development and severity of these infectious diseases. study subjects and sample collection Enrolled in this study were 121 hospitalized patients with HTNV infection from 2009 to 2011. the clinical diagnosis was confirmed by detection of IgM antibodies to HTNV in the patients' serum specimens. HTNV strain 76–118 was propagated on Vero E6 cells. quantitative analysis of mRNA expression was done by quantitative Real-time PCR using the SYBR Green detection method. the specific primers for each gene were shown in the supporting information table S2. each gene was normalized to the housekeeping gene GAPDH. the transfection of the siRNA into HUVECs was performed using lipo 2000 following the manufacturer's protocol. the validity and efficiency of the siRNA was identified by determining the mRNA and protein levels of corresponding target genes after transfecting the siRNA into HUVECs. biotin-labeled oligonucleotides were synthesized with the following sequences, for NF-B1 site, (5′-CATGGGACTTCCCCAGGAACAGC-3′ and 5′-GCTGTTTTCCTGGGGAAGTCCCATG-3′) and for ISRE site (5′-ATGTTTTGGAAACCTAATTC-3′ and 5′-GAATTAGGTTTCCTCT-3′) DNA-chromatin-antibody complexes were collected with protein G agarose beads. then, the DNA was purified and subjected to PCR amplification. ChIP assay also documented that p50, p65, and IRF7 bound directly to the promoter. at 48 h post-HTNV infection, both a 177-bp DNA fragment and a 200-bp DNA fragment containing the NF-B1 site and ISRE site in the CXCL10 promoter can be amplified successfully. the contradictory findings of CXCL10's role in either protecting or promoting infection may depend on the host immune status and genetic background. the higher CXCL10 level in the acute phase of HFRS is correlated significantly with the HFRS severity-indicating clinical parameters. this is good proof that the production of CXCL10 is correlated with the replication of the HTNV (Figure 1(d)). the mechanism for the induction of CXCL10 during HTNV infection is still unknown. the results of the transfection of poly (I:C) suggest that the CXCL10 could be induced by dsRNA, which may be the replicative intermediate generated during HTNV replication. mock viruses, which lose their ability in replication, fail to activate the expression of CXCL10. the contents of CXCL10 (10 kDa) in HFRS patients' serum drop to the normal level after the hemodialysis treatment. the patients suffering from a severe or critical HFRS have to be treated by hemodialysis [5] to remove the low molecular weight proteins, such as cytokines and chemokines. but hemodialysis has some serious side effects, such as bleeding, hypotension, infection, and anemia. the authors declare that there is no conflict of interests regarding the publication of this paper.
